As I understand, the Second Amendment was written as a protection against political tyranny. The Founding Fathers knew that the King of England had used a standing army to oppress the people in the past. The solution was a well regulated militia and to not limit arms ownership to those in the military. However, because of big advances in military technology it's difficult to see how the kinds of arms typically owned by modern American gun owners would be very effective against the type of arms used by those in the armed forces. We saw this in the recent Supreme Court decision. They chose to focus a lot on the role handguns could play in defending house and home against criminals, but seemed to have no problem with a ban on machine guns- the kind of guns that would logically seem to be most protected by the Second Amendment because of their usefulness in military conflicts which would make them a better deterrent against tyranny than other types of firearms. Thus, the Supreme Court chose to "strain at a gnat and swallow a camel" to use a Biblical idiom in their treatment of the Second Amendment.

Well there were a number of thoughts I had when I first read through this thread. I admit I was tempted to immediately get into the argument over misconstruing the militia preamble policy statement so that it becomes the sole reason for the RKBA, for I feel this argument has become the tail attempting to wag the dog. I also thought about responding to the alleged futility of armed resistance, but I will limit myself to note my disbelief that a bunch of citizens armed with rifles and shotguns will march out into a field, form square like they are about to receive cavalry at Waterloo, and patiently await the B-52 strike. I am instead going to address the first thought that crossed my mind when I read the argument for the RKBA’s “irrelevance.” 
 
 My first thought was that this argument on the alleged “irrelevance” of the individual RKBA is nothing more than a paraphrase of the very situation our founding fathers had sought to avoid—the creation of a standing army capable of threatening our liberties. Now I believe the intention of the militia clause of the 2nd. Amendment was to make the following very clear public policy statement: To preserve liberty we should rely upon militias and avoid standing armies. Many state constitutions already contained this public policy goal. See, for example, the Constitution of Virginia: "that standing armies, in time of peace, should be avoided, as dangerous to liberty." This is why the militia preference preamble of the 2nd. Amendment reads militias as “being necessary to the defense of a free state”—that is, a state which need not fear the ambitions of a tyrant. 
 
 And now we see the issue come full circle. The argument which starts this thread suggests that we can no longer defend ourselves should our professional armed forces turn upon us. You could paraphrase Patrick Henry and argue “the attempt would be madness,” and now suggest that the safety hazard outweighs any usefulness of the RKBA (based upon what I believe to be a mistaken assumption that the militia preamble is the sole justification for the right). I believe I understand the argument, even if I disagree with it. 
 
 I disagree with the principle of this argument because I think it promotes encroachment on all our civil liberties. I trust everyone agrees that the Bill of Rights was drafted and ratified as a check on the power of the federal government. I think we have to look at the “irrelevant” proposal with this in mind, particularly if we accept the underlying premise of the argument. To re-paraphrase the argument as I understand it: The government has created—however contrary to the intent of and against all advice of the nation’s founders—the very instrument of potential tyranny they sought to avoid, and that it has now made that instrument so powerful that the citizen can no longer defend against its ability to oppress him. In short, we now live in freedom at the discretion of our military, and therefore we need to abolish the 2nd. Amendment since it is no longer probable that through its protection we could save ourselves. 
 
 You know, this is a far better argument for reigning in our military establishment than one intended to support a total surrender to its potential power to tyrannize. 
 
 But here is my fundamental problem with this argument. It does not limit itself to a claim that the government has already made an end-run around one of the rights intended to protect us. It also asks that we be meekly complicit in that act. To put it another way, it suggests we should not only allow the federal government to seek out opportunities to side-step restrictions on its power by creating situations in which it can claim the right restricting it is no longer relevant or safe. It goes further to suggest we should endorse this action—that our response should be to reward the government for this behavior by surrendering the right it now claims to have made irrelevant. 
 
 How would such a reaction not encourage further encroachments upon our civil liberties? For me this is a dangerous argument to make at a time when we already see a government straining to justify holding people for years without trial or access to our courts. I for one am not in favor of encouraging the government to look for rights it thinks it can now avoid by declaring them irrelevant or too much of a safety hazard. 
 
 ---
 
 "False is the idea of utility that sacrifices a thousand real advantages for one imaginary or trifling inconvenience; that would take fire from men because it burns, and water because one may drown in it; that has no remedy for evils, except destruction. The laws that forbid the carrying of arms are laws of such a nature. They disarm only those who are neither inclined nor determined to commit crimes. Can it be supposed that those who have the courage to violate the most sacred laws of humanity, the most important of the code, will respect the less important and arbitrary ones, which can be violated with ease and impunity, and which, if strictly obeyed, would put an end to personal liberty--so dear to men, so dear to the enlightened legislator--and subject innocent persons to all the vexations that the guilty alone ought to suffer? Such laws make things worse for the assaulted and better for the assailants; they serve rather to encourage than to prevent homicides, for an unarmed man may be attacked with greater confidence than an armed man. The ought to be designated as laws not preventative but fearful of crimes, produced by the tumultuous impression of a few isolated facts, and not by thoughtful consideration of the inconveniences and advantages of a universal decree."--Thomas Jefferson, Commonplace Book, 1774-1776, quoting with approval 18th century criminologist Cesare Beccaria from his work, On Crimes and Punishment, 1764.
